Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of deaths caused by the second wave of the Spanish flu by stating that it killed 20 million to 50 million people.
Understate: The claim understates the number of deaths caused by the first wave of the Spanish flu by stating that it killed only 3 million to 5 million people.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide specific sources or data to back up the numbers mentioned.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that history will repeat itself in the case of COVID-19 without providing evidence or justification for this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert's verdict provides alternative explanations for the differences in death tolls between the first and second waves of the Spanish flu, such as less-advanced healthcare systems and incomplete records.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not acknowledging the limitations and uncertainties in determining the exact death toll of the Spanish flu due to incomplete and inaccurate records.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the exact death toll and case fatality rate of the Spanish flu are unknown due to incomplete and inaccurate records.
